bibl.title: Despatch from William H. Heard to Edwin F. Uhl, July 10, 1895
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, July 10/95.

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D. AUG 23 1895 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: William H. Heard, to the Department of State.
Loss by exchange by Vice Consul
Consulate General of the U.S. Monrovia, Liberia, July 10 1895.
Hon. Edwin F. Uhl, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to enclose, the explanation of vice consul Beverly Y. Payne for the Auditor of the Treasury. I find that to change drafts here one mst loose, 2 0/7. 3 0/0 and 4 0/0 never less than 2 0/0 and that an English Sterling is $4.80 only. Do we loose in all our wausalins86.66 on every sterling. But there
are afer persons who can furnish United States currency, and it is dollar for a dollar. Every gold dollar. Every Liberian dollar, and every paper note is worth 100 cents.
I am obediently William H. Heard Min. Res. and Con. General
Enclosure 1/6 Explanation of Vice Consul Payne
